![Switching Apps](/content/images/2015/03/Screen-Shot-2015-03-13-at-19-47-11-1.png)

All of the Mac apps I can't develop websites – or live – without.

#### Chrome Beta

Maybe it's just what I'm used to, but Chrome's developer tools seem unparalleled to me. Even with the fact that Safari looks incredible on Yosemite (even better in full-screen mode), I still have to use Chrome. I really look forward to the day when Google brings Material Design to desktop Chrome. I think that would look and feel much better on Yosemite.

I have to make the distinction with "Beta" here, because using the beta version ensures that I'm at least one step ahead of what my clients are using. This makes troubleshooting errors due to browser updates a more preemptive process for me. I don't like to use Canary, the bleeding-edge version, because key components of it can break from time to time and impede my workflow.

Of course within Chrome or any browser, there's a whole slew of other stuff you can talk about like extensions and the web apps you use, but [I'll save that for another post.](http://zackphilipps.com/how-i-use-chrome-to-run-a-web-design-business/)

#### Transmit

Wow, it's simply the best FTP client out there. Period. It's great for Mac users because it's only available for Mac (:P), and actually looks and behaves like a Finder window.

Why is it the best? It's simple to configure and use, you can save and sync connections on all your devices via Dropbox, and you can't beat the ability to double-click files on a remote server and have them automatically open up for editing in your favorite text editor. Then, when you save your edits, the remote file is automatically overwritten, eliminate the painfully endless loop of dragging and dropping. Oh, and it's extremely fast. (Obviously not as fast as just using the command line, but hey, take what you can get.)

#### Sublime Text

I love to customize things, which makes me greatly appreciate any software that lets me do it. Sublime is extremely customizable, and it's easy! You can set your own preferences and key-bindings. Plus, there is a huge, thriving community of developers that have made packages, themes, and color schemes for Sublime. I can and should talk about [my Sublime setup in another post](http://zackphilipps.com/a-front-end-developers-sublime-text-setup).

Sublime is also the fastest-launching text editor I have ever used. I hated waiting on Brackets / Edge Code to open up when I used them.

#### iTerm

iTerm is great because it's basically Mac OS's Terminal with several simple improvements. I love the fact that I can just quit the app and know it will automatically log me out of all my sessions. This makes shutting down my Mac a breeze (`ctrl+option+cmd+eject`).

The glue that holds Sublime and iTerm together though, and the main reason I use them, is [Mathias's dotfiles](https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles). Having set those up, I can type `s path/to/directory` to open an entire project in Sublime. I can also type in `emptytrash` to "Empty the Trash on all mounted volumes and the main HDD, and also clear Apple’s System Logs to improve shell startup speed", and then `cleanup` to recursively remove all `.DS_Store` files. I can also simply type `update` to single-commandedly get OS X Software Updates, and update installed Ruby gems, Homebrew, npm, and their installed packages. These are just a few of the aliases I use frequently that I have Mathias (and contributors to his GitHub repo) to thank for. Not to mention the awesome OSX, iTerm, and Sublime preferences and settings that are configured automatically upon executing `.osx`.

#### MAMP

I use this to develop WordPress websites locally. I use it because I must! It's a pretty elegant solution.

#### Messages

One of the few native Mac OS apps I use, the Yosemite version is pretty much indispensable. I can send and receive iMessages and SMS messages right from my computer, which is obviously AWESOME because typing on a keyboard is way faster than texting. There is also the ability to integrate other chat services, and I've set up Google Hangouts with mine. Messages and Mailbox have (almost) eliminated the need for me to ever open Gmail in the browser.

#### Slack

Slack is amazing. It's the perfect service to use for a work chatroom. It's even better for developers and designers because it makes file-sharing extremely easy, and it supports Markdown for your code-sharing needs. Plus, it has tons of subtle UI components that make it a delight to use.

#### Mailbox

Having already been using Mailbox on my iPhone and iPad, I was ecstatic to learn that the beta version for Mac OS was available to download. I love the magic mouse touch integrations, and I also love the keyboard shortcuts. I can respond to emails so much faster, and the design of the app is clean, minimal, and focus-oriented. The only caveat I've seen so far in the desktop app is that the search feature is a little lacking sometimes. That's why I occasionally find myself opening Gmail in a browser to find something that's particularly buried in the archives. That doesn't stop me from using Mailbox. It's still in beta after all.

#### Sunrise

I need Sunrise in my life because the design and UI of Google Calendars is god awful. Sunrise is beautiful and frees up precious tab space in my browser. Enough said.

#### Clear

Just like Mailbox, I had already been using Clear on my iPhone and iPad and loved it to death. The touch gestures make to-do lists fun, and the app translates well on desktop. I use it for my personal task list, since it's not meant to be a solution for project management.

## Background Apps

These are apps that I rarely ever open (because I don't have to), but I use them daily nonetheless.

#### 1Password

As a web developer, I have hundreds of login credentials to keep track of (and create) for myself and my clients. 1Password makes it simple to create strong passwords because it takes care of remembering them for you. After you install the app and browser extension, you can use the (brilliant) `cmd+\` shortcut to instantly log in to any service. You can also store addresses and credit cards to make checkout processes a little easier.

It's also a safer alternative to browser Autofill or iCloud keychains because all of your credentials are stored in a "vault" that requires a master passphrase to unlock. The vault locks automatically after a specified duration of inactive time. In addition, if you're like me and didn't get the app via the Mac App Store, you can sync your vault across all devices using Dropbox, provided you've installed on each device.

#### Dropbox

I use Dropbox because it provides an easy way to sync my 1Password vault, my Sublime preferences, and my Transmit favorites. For all other files I could use an alternative service, but Dropbox wins because it integrates with the essentials. Most of my clients also share files this way.

#### Spectacle

Spectacle was the best free Mac OS window manager I could find. I really enjoy the keyboard shortcuts and the fact that you can customize them. I frequently use `ctrl+option+cmd+→` (or `←`) to move apps between monitors, as well as `ctrl+option+cmd+F` to make windows take up the entire screen without entering full-screen mode.

#### CopyClip

It's a clipboard manager. Keeps track of things I `cmd+C` from any app, and provides a nice list of my history accessible via the Mac OS toolbar. Need it!

#### Screenmailer

Without this, I would never be able to teach my clients how to manage their websites. Screenmailer lives in my OSX menu bar, and when I'm ready to record my screen, I click its icon and click "Record". When I'm done, I stop the recording, and click a button to copy its newly-generated URL to my clipboard. [Here's a screenmailer video of me writing this post.](https://www.screenmailer.com/v/a4tg7NBsKarkTwY)

posts.title: Introducing New Layout Functions and ACF Shortcuts
posts.markdown:
Hello all! If you're an avid [Scratch Theme for WordPress](//scratchtheme.com) user, this post applies to you. If you use WordPress to develop websites, and you're not using Scratch yet, my only question is... why not?! I just wanted to announce the release of [v1.2](//scratchtheme.com/changelog) and bring some important and awesome features to your attention. So, here goes! ### New Layout Functions If you've taken a look at the *advanced* section of the Scratch Docs, you know all about [Layout Functions](http://scratchtheme.com/docs/advanced/#layout-functions). They're great for plugging posts within The Loop into a CSS grid, or plugging sub-fields within an ACF Repeater into a CSS grid. Scratch features 1-6 column Layout Functions, as well as some flexible functions that allow you to completely fill the space in the last row with whatever number of posts or sub-fields is left over. One of the issues with Layout Functions was that sometimes you had to give your posts or sub-fields (let's call the space they take up "cells") a `height`. Until now. With the new Layout Functions, each row of cells is wrapped in a `div.clearfix`. This means no more unnecessary heights. Everything just works! In addition, the means of declaring said layouts is now easier. Don't worry; you can still use the old Layout Functions and they will work well enough. But with the new functions, you don't have to declare `$count` or `$blocks` anymore. Here's an example using an ACF Repeater: The full function to declare the layout looks like this (parameters below): scratch_layout_declare($args, $columns, $flex = true, $offset = null, $option = null) #### Parameters **$args** * (array) `WP_Query` arguments * (string) ACF `$field_name` **$columns** * (int) Number of columns to build to (if `4`, `four_columns_flex()` will be used) * (string) `custom` (`custom_columns()` will be used) **$flex** * (bool) Whether or not to use the layout functions ending in `_flex` **$offset** * (string) Offset to use, if any *Only applicable for 2 and 3 column layouts * `1:2` * `2:1` * `1:1:2` * `1:2:1` * `2:1:1` **$option** * (mixed) ACF option, if any: get_field($field_name, $option) Feel free to look around [layout-declarations.php](https://github.com/zackphilipps/scratch-theme/blob/master/core/php/layout-declarations.php) if you fancy a more hands-on learning experience. ### ACF Shortcuts Let's say you wanted to build a button with a href and title set by ACF. This is pretty common. You'd have to type all of this out:

What if you could produce all of this with a one-liner? Well, you can. You could've written this on your own pretty easily. But, if you haven't yet for some reason, Scratch provides this: scratch_button($href, $title, $classes = null, $option = null) This is just one of the many ACF Shortcuts now baked into Scratch. For more, visit [acf-shortcuts.php](https://github.com/zackphilipps/scratch-theme/blob/master/core/php/acf-shortcuts.php). ### Layouts Page Template To play around with this, create a new page in WordPress and set its template to "Layouts". With Scratch, you can now add robust layouts on the fly, including sliders, hero units, staggered columns, and more. In addition, you have full control over [layouts/layout-*.php](https://github.com/zackphilipps/scratch-theme/tree/master/layouts) and [_layouts.scss](https://github.com/zackphilipps/scratch-theme/blob/master/scss/_layouts.scss) for customization. ~~ACF does not currently support editing the field groups themselves, but as per this post, that feature should be in the roadmap.~~ **Update:** Editing the field groups from the Custom Fields screen is now possible through [synchronized JSON](http://www.advancedcustomfields.com/resources/synchronized-json/)! ### Conclusion Hopefully some of this got you more excited about working with Scratch and ACF. I know it's definitely saving hours of mine and my coworkers' time building great websites for clients whose demands are steadily growing. --- #### Related Posts - [A WordPress Development Workflow for Small Teams in 2015](http://zackphilipps.com/a-wordpress-development-workflow-for-small-teams-in-2015/)

Hello all! If you're an avid Scratch Theme for WordPress user, this post applies to you. If you use WordPress to develop websites, and you're not using Scratch yet, my only question is... why not?!

I just wanted to announce the release of v1.2 and bring some important and awesome features to your attention. So, here goes!

New Layout Functions

If you've taken a look at the advanced section of the Scratch Docs, you know all about Layout Functions. They're great for plugging posts within The Loop into a CSS grid, or plugging sub-fields within an ACF Repeater into a CSS grid. Scratch features 1-6 column Layout Functions, as well as some flexible functions that allow you to completely fill the space in the last row with whatever number of posts or sub-fields is left over. One of the issues with Layout Functions was that sometimes you had to give your posts or sub-fields (let's call the space they take up "cells") a height. Until now.

With the new Layout Functions, each row of cells is wrapped in a div.clearfix. This means no more unnecessary heights. Everything just works!

In addition, the means of declaring said layouts is now easier. Don't worry; you can still use the old Layout Functions and they will work well enough. But with the new functions, you don't have to declare $count or $blocks anymore. Here's an example using an ACF Repeater:

<?php
  scratch_layout_declare('repeater', 4);
  while(has_sub_field('repeater')) {
    scratch_layout_start();
?>
  <!-- Content goes here. -->
<?php
    scratch_layout_end();
  }
?>

The full function to declare the layout looks like this (parameters below):

scratch_layout_declare($args, $columns, $flex = true, $offset = null, $option = null)

Parameters

$args

  • (array) WP_Query arguments
  • (string) ACF $field_name

$columns

  • (int) Number of columns to build to (if 4, four_columns_flex() will be used)
  • (string) custom (custom_columns() will be used)

$flex

  • (bool) Whether or not to use the layout functions ending in _flex

$offset

  • (string) Offset to use, if any *Only applicable for 2 and 3 column layouts
    • 1:2
    • 2:1
    • 1:1:2
    • 1:2:1
    • 2:1:1

$option

  • (mixed) ACF option, if any:

    get_field($field_name, $option)

Feel free to look around layout-declarations.php if you fancy a more hands-on learning experience.

ACF Shortcuts

Let's say you wanted to build a button with a href and title set by ACF. This is pretty common. You'd have to type all of this out:

<?php if(get_field('link_text')) { ?>
  <p>
    <a class="button"
       href="<?php the_field('link_href'); ?>"
       title="<?php the_field('link_text'); ?>">
      <?php the_field('link_text'); ?>
    </a>
  </p>
<?php } ?>

What if you could produce all of this with a one-liner? Well, you can. You could've written this on your own pretty easily. But, if you haven't yet for some reason, Scratch provides this: 

scratch_button($href, $title, $classes = null, $option = null)

This is just one of the many ACF Shortcuts now baked into Scratch. For more, visit acf-shortcuts.php.

Layouts Page Template

To play around with this, create a new page in WordPress and set its template to "Layouts". With Scratch, you can now add robust layouts on the fly, including sliders, hero units, staggered columns, and more. In addition, you have full control over layouts/layout-*.php and _layouts.scss for customization.

ACF does not currently support editing the field groups themselves, but as per this post, that feature should be in the roadmap.

Update: Editing the field groups from the Custom Fields screen is now possible through synchronized JSON!

Conclusion

Hopefully some of this got you more excited about working with Scratch and ACF. I know it's definitely saving hours of mine and my coworkers' time building great websites for clients whose demands are steadily growing.

posts.title: A Saner iPhone Setup
posts.markdown:
There's a lot to do on an iPhone, and it can easily get overwhelming. Here's how I've dealt with it.

### Settings

I've turned all **notifications** OFF except for calls & messages, calendar alerts, reminders, weather alerts, directions, and server downtime alerts. Compare that with getting buzzed every time I received an email, Slack notification, or social media notification, and it's a MUCH better experience.

In addition, I have **Do Not Disturb** turned on from 9:30 p.m. until 6:30 a.m.

This is just my personal preference, but I almost always have **Portrait Orientation Lock** turned on.

~~Obviously configure your phone to show your **battery percentage** in the status bar.~~ I've found that with all of the other littles icons up there, the percentage clutters it up too much. Also, with iPhone 6, battery life tends to last long enough that I don't have to worry about the percentage.

I've set **Auto-Lock** to 5 minutes instead of the default 1 minute, and if nothing else it's made grocery shopping using a list on my phone much easier!

I've found my phone's screen to be too bright in the dark even when **brightness** is turned all the way down, so [I've implemented this trick from Lifehacker](http://lifehacker.com/toggle-your-iphones-brightness-with-a-home-button-trip-1651329242).

I also have **Reduce Motion** turned on because I've found that my phone performs better and has increased battery life.

### Apps / Home Screen

I've managed to clear my home screen of everything except two folders in my dock. To see how, and to get a glimpse of some of my favorite iOS apps, check this out:

posts.title: Idol Couples
posts.markdown:
When you're lucky enough to be in a serious, committed relationship with your best friend (read: like me), you start to notice that you and your partner begin idolizing certain couples. And, if you are a serious consumer of entertainment because it's better than real life (again), these couples are usually in the spotlight.

This romantic phenomenon occurs because you and your partner both hope that you as a couple can someday be as great as the following couples (in case you didn't know what "idolizing" means ¯\\_(ツ)_/¯).

---

#### Bey Z – Beyoncé and Jay Z

![Bey Z](/content/images/2015/03/beyz.jpg)

I'm sure there aren't many people on the planet that **don't** idolize these two, but I have to mention them anyway because we as the human race honestly can't give them enough praise. Sure, they've had problems with cheating and baby stress, but they're both such insanely hard workers and so dedicated to each other that they'll never let that get in the way.

I hope one day to build an empire of success with my significant other and still keep our relationship in tact. This does not mean I'm going to start rapping; I think everyone can learn something from the way Jay and Bey handle their business(es). Basically they're both individuals, good people, and they don't tolerate disrespect. Or as Jay puts it, "Baby I'm a boss, I don't know what they do / I don't get dropped, I drop the label." OR, as Bey puts it...

![Beyoncé bein' sassy](/content/images/2015/03/bey1.gif)
![Beyoncé bein' sassy](/content/images/2015/03/bey2.gif)
![Beyoncé bein' sassy](/content/images/2015/03/bey3.gif)
![Beyoncé bein' sassy](/content/images/2015/03/bey4.gif)

---

#### Krax – Kristen Bell and Dax Shepard

![Krax](/content/images/2015/03/krax.jpg)

Our love for Krax really stems from the movie [Hit and Run](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2097307/); which was written, directed, and led by Dax himself, who calls it "a love letter to Kristen Bell." Well, that, and [Kristen's love for sloths](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t5jw3T3Jy70). (Dax has some pretty good clips on Ellen as well.)

Following Kristen on Twitter, however, reveals her humanitarian side. It doesn't seem like a day goes by that Kristen isn't trying to raise awareness for something that both deserves and needs more awareness. Not to mention that she's an extremely talented actor and singer, most notably demonstrated by her role as Anna in Frozen. Can't wait to see what else this couple has in store for us!

---

#### The Ponds

![Amy and Rory](/content/images/2015/05/wedding_01.jpg)

As far as fictional couples go, this has got to be one of our all-time favorites. The fact that Doctor Who started to go downhill with the slow and dreadful realization that these two actors had to move on is a testament to how integral they were to the show.

And can we please talk about how hilariously awesome it is that The Doctor continually referred to them as the Ponds? If you have no idea what I'm talking about but for some reason are still reading, Pond is AMY's last name. All jokes aside, I'm sure Rory would have had no problem making that compromise. And that's what relationships are all about – commitment and mutual sacrifice. Well, and time-traveling adventures that usually result in either the extermination or preservation of an entire species.

---

#### The Obamas

![The Obamas](/content/images/2015/05/obama-family.jpg)

Complain about President Obama all you want, as you do, but I'm extremely proud to have had him as a president these last eight years. He has been an innovator in a lot of ways. First black president, first president to use the term "transgender" in the State of the Union address, first president to make good use of social media... and I'm sure there are more firsts. posts.markdown:
This post – as well as my other post [A Front End Developer’s Daily App Stack](http://zackphilipps.com/a-front-end-developers-daily-app-stack/) – is 100% inspired by [A Designer’s Sublime Text Setup](https://medium.com/design-notes/a-designers-sublime-text-setup-e3963f8d79da).

If you're following along, as a prerequisite you should definitely upgrade to [Sublime Text 3](http://www.sublimetext.com/3) if you haven't already, and likewise [install Package Control](https://packagecontrol.io/installation).

---

### Theme & Color Scheme

![Theme and color scheme](/content/images/2015/03/Screen-Shot-2015-03-27-at-12-28-43.png)

Having started with [Flatland](https://github.com/thinkpixellab/flatland), I am currently using [Predawn](https://github.com/jamiewilson/predawn). I love it so much... It has a color scheme built in, and even its own icon set and dock icon, as well as suggested settings and packages! I owe my entire Sublime setup to Jamie Wilson and [Mathias Bynens](https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles).

---

### Key Bindings

Like [Matej Latin](https://medium.com/@matejlatin), I had also been using Brackets for a while before I switched to Sublime. I also had a lot of difficulty adjusting to the new keybindings for *Duplicate Line* and *Delete Line*. To emulate this in Sublime, simply navigate to Preferences > Key Bindings – User and add this:

	[
    { "keys": ["super+d"], "command": "duplicate_line" },
	{ "keys": ["super+shift+d"], "command": "run_macro_file", "args": {"file": "Packages/Default/Delete Line.sublime-macro"} }
    ]
    
However I actually have all of my Sublime preferences synced with my entire development team at work (more on that later – has its pros and cons), and one of them really liked the *Quick Add Next* default behavior of `command+D`, so I got used to this instead:

	{ "keys": ["super+alt+d"], "command": "duplicate_line" }
    
To make that work, I had to go to *System Preferences > Keyboard > Shortcuts > Launchpad & Dock* and uncheck the box for *Turn Dock Hiding On/Off*.

I'm also a huge fan of [snippets](http://sublimetext.info/docs/en/extensibility/snippets.html), so I wanted a handy shortcut to pop open a list of snippets. This did the trick:

	{ "keys": ["ctrl+s"], "command": "show_overlay", "args": {"overlay": "command_palette", "text": "Snippet: "}}
    
I also have the package [FixMyJS](http://addyosmani.com/blog/fixmyjs/) installed, so the shortcut to use that is:

	{ "keys": ["alt+super+j"], "command": "fix" }
    
So to recap, and for the sake of quick updating in the future, my entire keybindings file looks like this:

	[
    { "keys": ["super+shift+d"], "command": "run_macro_file", "args": {"file": "Packages/Default/Delete Line.sublime-macro"} },
    { "keys": ["ctrl+s"], "command": "show_overlay", "args": {"overlay": "command_palette", "text": "Snippet: "}},
    { "keys": ["alt+super+j"], "command": "fix" },
    { "keys": ["super+alt+d"], "command": "duplicate_line" },
    ]

---

### Preferences

My preferences are a combination of Mathias's and Jamie's preferences with a few little tweaks of my own. My tweaks are mostly typography-related (I use 14 pt. with a bottom line padding of 4 because I like to be able to see my code), but I also have `find_selected_text` set to `true` (another Brackets-inspo'd behavior). I've also implemented [Ben Frain's top tip to stop hyphens from separating words](http://benfrain.com/top-tips-selection-unrelated-front-end-developer-tips). Here's my entire preferences file:

	{
	"close_windows_when_empty": false,
	"color_scheme": "Packages/Predawn/predawn.tmTheme",
	"default_encoding": "UTF-8",
	"default_line_ending": "unix",
	"detect_indentation": false,
	"draw_indent_guides": true,
	"draw_minimap_border": true,
	"draw_white_space": "all",
	"enable_tab_scrolling": false,
	"ensure_newline_at_eof_on_save": false,
	"file_exclude_patterns":
	[
		".DS_Store",
		"Desktop.ini",
		"*.pyc",
		"._*",
		"Thumbs.db",
		".Spotlight-V100",
		".Trashes"
	],
	"find_selected_text": true,
	"folder_exclude_patterns":
	[
		".git",
		"node_modules"
	],
	"font_size": 14,
	"highlight_modified_tabs": true,
	"hot_exit": false,
	"ignored_packages":
	[
		"Vintage"
	],
	"indent_guide_options":
	[
		"draw_active"
	],
	"line_padding_bottom": 4,
	"match_brackets": true,
	"match_brackets_angle": true,
	"open_files_in_new_window": false,
	"overlay_scroll_bars": "enabled",
	"remember_open_files": false,
	"show_encoding": true,
	"show_line_endings": true,
	"sidebar_default": true,
	"tab_size": 2,
	"tabs_small": true,
	"theme": "predawn.sublime-theme",
	"translate_tabs_to_spaces": false,
	"trim_trailing_white_space_on_save": true,
	"word_separators": "./\\()\"':,.;<>~!@#$%^&*|+=[]{}`~?",
	"word_wrap": true
	}


---

### Packages

[ACF Snippets](https://github.com/smilledge/acf-sublime-snippets) – For [Advanced Custom Fields for WordPress](http://advancedcustomfields.com). I <3 it. With the baked-in PHP snippet, I can now type `php`, tab, `ifgf`, tab, and then type in the field name as opposed to typing `<?php if(get_field('field_name')): ?>` which is very awkward.

[Color Highlighter](https://github.com/Monnoroch/ColorHighlighter) – Unobtrusively previews hexadecimal color values by underlaying the selected hex codes in different styles.

[Emmet](http://emmet.io/) – Another time-saving package, as now I can type `!`, `tab` as opposed to (along with MANY MANY others):

	<!DOCTYPE html>
	<html lang="en">
	<head>
		<meta charset="UTF-8">
		<title>Document</title>
	</head>
	<body>
		
	</body>
	</html>

[FixMyJS](http://addyosmani.com/blog/fixmyjs/) – Just click the link and read Addy's post.

[GitGutter](https://github.com/jisaacks/GitGutter) – This is both part of [Mathias's dotfiles](https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles) and suggested by Jamie. It's amazing.

[Handlebars](https://github.com/daaain/Handlebars) – Handlebars syntax support.

[JavaScript Beautify](https://github.com/enginespot/js-beautify-sublime) – Automatically formats my JS just the way I like every time I hit *Save.*

[Package Syncing](https://github.com/csch0/SublimeText-Package-Syncing) – Suggested by Matej and <3'd by many. Uses Dropbox to sync your Sublime preferences across devices. This is what we use at work so we all have the same ST3 setup. Referenced in the post about [my daily app stack](http://zackphilipps.com/a-front-end-developers-daily-app-stack/).

[Sass](https://packagecontrol.io/packages/Sass) – Sass syntax support.

[SassBeautify](https://github.com/badsyntax/SassBeautify) – Automatically formats my SCSS just the way I like every time I hit *Save.*

[SelectUntil](https://github.com/xavi-/sublime-selectuntil) – Lets me press `cmd+shift+L` to get a cursor on each line I've selected. This way I can bulk edit multiple lines where the characters are all different but the lengths are the same. Useful for editing file/directory structures I've copied from the command line where find & replace just doesn't cut it.

[SideBarEnhancements](https://github.com/titoBouzout/SideBarEnhancements) – Recommended by Jamie and <3'd by many. Lets me do a million things when I right-click files/folders in ST3's sidebar as opposed to virtually nothing.

[WordPress](https://github.com/purplefish32/sublime-text-2-wordpress) – If you work with a lot of WP sites, this is indispensable.

---

#### Related Posts

- [A Front End Developer’s Daily App Stack](http://zackphilipps.com/a-front-end-developers-daily-app-stack/)
- [A WordPress Development Workflow for Small Teams in 2015](http://zackphilipps.com/a-wordpress-development-workflow-for-small-teams-in-2015/)
- [How I Use Chrome to Run a Web Design Business](http://zackphilipps.com/how-i-use-chrome-to-run-a-web-design-business/)

posts.markdown:
![How I Use Chrome to Run a Web Design Business](/content/images/2015/04/google-chrome-2.jpg)

As previously mentioned in [A Front End Developer’s Daily App Stack](http://zackphilipps.com/a-front-end-developers-daily-app-stack/), I use Chrome Beta even though I'd like to use Safari on Yosemite because I strongly prefer Chrome's DevTools. I thought it would be fun to write about some of the web apps I use as well as my Chrome extensions.

---

## Web Apps

**Note:** Most of these are freemium, meaning you can enjoy a majority of the features without having to pay a dime.

### Asana

At [Tribeswell](http://tribeswell.com), we use [Asana](http://asana.com) for **project management.** It does a very good job of staying out of our way and keeping us out of email for internal communications. (Well, Slack helps too.)

What I really like about Asana is the keyboard shortcuts for assigning tasks and giving them due dates. It also lets you choose the view of tasks and projects that makes the most sense for you. Another feature I find myself using constantly is [emailing tasks to Asana](https://asana.com/guide/help/email/email-to-asana). Asana will automatically pull all the contents of the email, including attachments, and create a task out of it.

### Toggl

We use [Toggl](http://toggl.com) for **time tracking.** It's definitely the simplest and best-looking time tracker I've ever seen. We actually use it for logging employees' hours as well as tracking billable hours for clients. Toggl's beautiful report system makes viewing hours over custom date ranges effortless and even fun.

Plus, once you install the [Toggl Button browser extension](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/toggl-button/oejgccbfbmkkpaidnkphaiaecficdnfn?hl=en), you get these neat little Toggl buttons all over the place. On a task in Asana, an issue in GitHub, a Google Doc or Sheet, I can simply click "Start timer" to start tracking my time.

**Note:** Asana and Toggl are two out of the three [tabs I always have pinned](http://www.techrepublic.com/blog/tech-sanity-check/how-to-use-pin-tab-to-organize-your-work-in-google-chrome/).

### Nusii

![Nusii Dashboard](/content/images/2015/04/Screen-Shot-2015-04-03-at-21-23-53.png)

I use [Nusii](http://nusii.com/#_l_1c) for **proposals.** It lets me use templates, and gets even more modular than that by allowing me to create and save reusable sections. The sections can be either text-based or price-based. Nusii is designed so that I can offer my clients tiered pricing options. I can include fixed prices or prices per hour, day, or month. They've also recently added a digital signing feature which is pretty awesome.

When I'm done writing a proposal – thanks to Nusii it now takes WAY less time – I can send it to the client straight from the app and get a notification email whenever the client views it. The client can then choose (a) pricing option(s) and accept the proposal right in the browser. Don't worry, there's the option to download and print a PDF version if the client so desires. Oh, and both the PDF and the web-based version are **drop dead gorgeous.**

Other features include custom branding and color scheme and a custom URL that all of your proposals can be accessed from (ours is **proposals.tribeswell.com**).

### Kashoo

We use [Kashoo](http://kashoo.com) for **cloud accounting.** It handles all of our invoices from creation to sendoff to clearance. It also features a very robust reporting system so we can compare profit & loss using custom date ranges. Another thing we constantly do is glance at all of our aging receivables to see which clients have invoices that are still out and how long they've been out.

### Calendly

![Calendly User Interface](/content/images/2015/04/Screen-Shot-2015-04-03-at-21-26-07.png)

I use [Calendly](http://calendly.com) (shoutout to [Marcus Blankenship](http://www.marcusblankenship.com/)) for **scheduling appointments.** People who want to meet with me can use my personal link and schedule appointments themselves. This eliminates about ten emails & phone calls back and forth trying to figure out a day and time that works.

### Buffer

Tribeswell isn't much into the **social media** game at the moment, but when we are, [Buffer](https://buffer.com/) is nice because it allows managing our Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter accounts from a central location. It also takes care of evenly scheduling posts and automatically... posting... them which is great for us and our followers.

### Strictly Dev

I'll talk about these more in-depth [in another post](http://zackphilipps.com/a-wordpress-development-workflow-for-small-teams-in-2015/), but for now:

 * GitHub
 * Bitbucket
 * DigitalOcean
 * Codeship
 * Stack Overflow
 * New Relic

### Etc.

Since everyone should be using these, here are some that don't deserve their own sections but rather honorable mentions:

 * All things Google
 * My social media inlets of choice: Tumblr, Twitter

---

## Extensions

### Shipscope

Shipscope is [CodeShip's browser extension](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/shipscope/jdedmgopefelimgjceagffkeeiknclhh?hl=en) that shows me a list of all of my projects and their build statuses. I opted out of email or Slack notifications for my builds and decided to use this instead.

### Font Face Ninja

posts.title: What to Do if Your WordPress Website is "Down"
posts.markdown:
![This webpage is not available](/content/images/2015/04/Screen-Shot-2015-04-22-at-21-24-09-1.png)

Recently I was tasked with drafting a simple document explaining to coworkers what to do if a website is misbehaving. I thought I would share my small amount of insight. Full disclaimer – this is for developers.

Often times, when searching for a fix online, we race through results and may miss the answer we were looking for several times before we finally see it. No doubt there are several blog posts just like this all over the web, but I don't think adding mine to the mix will hurt. It should hopefully increase your chances of finding your answer faster!

### Step 1 – Do not panic!

First make sure that the site is actually down. Sometimes sites will become briefly unavailable and then bounce back within seconds.

### Step 2 – Figure out where your website is hosted.

Where the site is hosted will affect the process needed to fix the issue.

### Step 3 – Double check the error message if there is one, and determine your next step.

- Does it say “Briefly unavailable for scheduled maintenance”? If so, WordPress core or one or more WordPress plugins are updating. If this message does not disappear (and the site return to normal) within 2 minutes, something else may be wrong.
- Does it say “Error establishing a database connection”? This could mean one of several things.
  - The `wp-config.php` file is messed up. Either the database name, database user, database password, or database host information is incorrect. All 4 pieces could be wrong. This usually only happens when sites are being set up or moved around.
  - Either the web server’s OR the data server’s `mysql` service could have stopped. You can check the status of `mysql` by running the `sudo service mysql status` command. If it has stopped, simply run `sudo service mysql start` or `sudo service mysql restart`.
  - If the site uses a remote database connection, the data server could be down (not likely if the data server is only used for data). Check the database host information in `wp-config.php`. If it says anything other than `localhost`, the database is being hosted remotely.
  - If the site uses a remote database connection, the server could have closed off remote communications temporarily due to an attack (also not likely). If this is the case, a reboot may be necessary. If you cannot perform the reboot safely yourself, call your hosting provider's support line.
  - If the site is on a reseller account, there is a high chance that the resources allocated to that particular client have been exceeded. These issues usually resolve themselves pretty quickly, but if the error is repeatedly occurring, you may need to boost that client’s hosting package. If you’ve never done this before, call your hosting provider's support line and ask them to check it out/walk you through the issue. Make sure you secure any appropriate login credentials you may need before making the call.
- Does it say “504 Bad Gateway”? This is usually a configuration issue. There’s not much you can do besides reconfigure (re-start the whole setup from scratch) or call your hosting provider's support line and ask them to check it out/walk you through the issue. Make sure you secure any appropriate login credentials you may need before making the call.
- Does it say something along the lines of “The server stopped responding”? First double-check your internet connection. If Google and Facebook work, then the server itself may be down. You can confirm this by visiting the primary domains of the server itself (ex: myserver.tribeswell.com). If the server is down, a reboot may be necessary. If you cannot perform the reboot safely yourself, call your hosting provider's support line.
- Does it say “500 Internal Server Error”, "403 Forbidden", or "401 Unauthorized", or something else about browsing not being permitted? This is almost always a file ownership/permissions issue and usually only occurs during setup or site migration. You need to reconfigure or contact your hosting provider to figure out the permissions issue.
- Most other error messages are likely PHP syntax errors. This means you or someone else wrote bad code and it needs to be fixed. The error message should point you to the exact file and line of code that caused the error.
 
### Step 4 – If there is no error message, what’s wrong?

- Does the site just pull up a blank white screen? This is likely due to a PHP syntax error. The error would have to occur early on in the code’s execution to prevent the rest of the page from loading, like in `functions.php` or `header.php`.
  - **Tip:** try renaming the `plugins` directory to `_plugins` to see if the issue is with a plugin, or renaming the `themes` directory to `_themes` to see if the issue is with  the theme.
- Are elements on the page behaving weirdly? Open up Dev Tools and check the JavaScript Console. If there are JS errors, it could be a JS issue. If not, it’s a CSS issue.
Is something just broken and you can’t explain it? Probably a PHP syntax error. Try this to get an error message displayed:

Replace `define( 'WP_DEBUG', false );` in `wp-config.php` with:

	error_reporting(E_ALL);
	ini_set('display_errors', 1);
	define( 'WP_DEBUG', true );

posts.title: What Great Customer Service is Made Of
posts.markdown:
![McDonald's Deliciousness](/content/images/2015/06/6066296925_004c79265c_b.jpg)

So, not long ago, my fiancée and I decided we wanted some McDonald's. This is the kind of craving that only happens once in a while, but when it does, it's **strong...** and cannot be satisfied by any other food or food provider.

Right now you're probably thinking, "Great customer service? At a McDonald's?" Just... please be patient and keep reading.

The older I get, the worse my memory gets, and so I cannot recall what entrees we ordered, but here's what I do remember: They forgot the fries. Now, when we order McDonald's, we do what any self-respecting McDonald's eater does. We eat the fries in the car on the way to our destination. Who has time to wait for fries? The hotter they are, the better. It's like the wounds that are opened up by the napalm-like frying oil on the roof of your mouth allow you to take in even more delicious salty McPotato flavor.

So, needless to say, we turned that car around real quick. Now, here's what I'm talking about. As soon as I walked in the door, receipt in hand, the guy in charge was like "You back for your fries?" I'm saying, "Yes," and thinking, "YAAAAAAAAS bless you holy man for taking the pressure off of me to explain myself. Now I have to interact with you less, which makes me like you more."

He's already standing by the fryers, waiting on the fries to finish. To fill the silence, he says, "You about to get some GOOD ones, too. These'll be HOT and FRESH." While giggling like a little kid, I say "Awesome," but I'm thinking, "YAAAAAAAS!"

So to recap, as soon as I walked in the door, he made me appreciative. Now he's got me laughing and feeling all warm and fuzzy inside.

He scoops up the fries, overfills two large cups (I'm pretty sure we ordered mediums), puts them in a bag, grabs about 50 napkins, and puts them in the bag as well. He walks over to the counter, and I'm thinking this is it. I'm satisfied. But it doesn't end there!

He pulls out some coupons that look like business cards, and starts thumbing through them. He says, "Now, for our mistake, I'mma give you a little something special on us. You like muffins?" I shrug and say, "Yeah!" He hands me a coupon for a free muffin. He then says, "You got a girlfriend or somethin'?" I nod. "Here's one for her too." I say, "Thanks, man. I really appreciate that." He says, "You have a great day, now." I say, "You, too," and walk out of there beaming.

And THAT, folks, is what great customer service is made of. Notice that he exceeded my expectations so much, he didn't even have to say sorry!

---

I felt like writing about this, because I know food service and retail jobs suck. I worked at a Steak 'n Shake for two years. I was a manager for 8 of those 24 months. The corporate heirarchy makes unreasonable demands, a lot of employees aren't helpful because they don't get paid enough to care, and a lot of customers just don't get it and are thusly rude. Plus the work itself is monotonous and tedious at best, completely physically and mentally overwhelming at worst. And I'm a white male! I can't imagine adding harassment to that shitstorm.

Anyway, I just feel like no matter how shitty my day was, I was always, at a bare minimum, polite to customers. After all, as an employee, you have no idea how shitty your customer's day is. I guess the overall lesson here is, treat others the way you would like to be treated. Let's take care of each other, people. Life is too harsh and short to not. You've heard it all before, but certain things can't be said enough.

On the flip side, [like Bey Z, don't tolerate disrespect](http://zackphilipps.com/idol-couples/). ;)

posts.title: A WordPress Development Workflow for Small Teams in 2015
posts.markdown:
![Coding and such with big monitors](/content/images/2015/07/19.jpg)

The future of web development is here, and has been for a while. I'm talking about front end tools that speed up workflow like Grunt and Sass. The developers that work on WordPress core know that, and they are utilizing it. WordPress theme developers even utilize it. Maybe even plugin developers. So why can't we utilize it on a per-project basis when developing WordPress websites?

We **can.** We **can** develop every WordPress site locally. We **can** use Grunt, Sass, and NPM on every single project. If we must, we **can** even share our local sites with the outside world for previewing or collaborating.

We **don't** have to install a different WordPress plugin for each front end tool we want to use. We **don't** have to do all of our development work on remote servers. Even though that may seem easier or faster, it's not ideal. You need to have a way to stage a bunch of work without affecting what's already there.

A WordPress fundamental that really complicates things is this: **the codebase and the database are completely separate from each other.** So we need an easy way to migrate the site's code from local to development server and back, to production server. We also need a separate way to do this with the database.

Here's a list of the tools that are instrumental in making this happen:

- [MAMP](https://www.mamp.info/en/)
- [Scratch](http://scratchtheme.com)
- [Bitbucket](https://bitbucket.org/)
- [DigitalOcean](https://www.digitalocean.com/)
- [Codeship](https://codeship.com)
- [WP Sync DB](https://github.com/wp-sync-db/wp-sync-db)

Below, I'll explain these tools in a bit more detail. After that, I'll explain how to use them. You might want to get in the tutorial-following mood to continue reading, but following along isn't required for learning. And you can certainly use different tools.

---

#### MAMP

[MAMP](https://www.mamp.info/en/) stands for Mac, Apache, MySQL, and PHP. It's what we use to develop WordPress sites locally. You have to have it or something comparable. I like MAMP PRO because it's so easy to use and has a nice design.

#### Scratch

[Scratch](http://scratchtheme.com) is the world's first [Advanced Custom Fields](http://advancedcustomfields.com/)-ready WordPress theme. It's not so much a theme as a springboard for building your own fully custom WordPress themes.

    function wpse16975_check_loggedin() {

    }

posts.title: A Fan's Journey with BTBAM
posts.markdown:
![Between the Buried and Me](/content/images/2016/03/Between-the-Buried-and-Me-2015.jpg)

It's been a long journey. But all journeys come to an end. This one ends with an album called *Coma Ecliptic*.

For those of you that aren't familiar, BTBAM stands for Between the Buried and Me – my favorite band. They are a 5-person progressive metal outfit from Raleigh, North Carolina. If you are one of those people who hear "metal" and think "Slipknot," then we're not on the same page. The metal that I know and love is a lot heavier and harder to play than any Slipknot song.

In fact, my appreciation for BTBAM is all about the sheer talent with which they play their instruments, and their songwriting prowess. I've always been into music. I play guitar, drums, and piano, and I can hit notes with my okay voice. Drums are my strong suit, and thus are the primary lens with which I view all music. I look for sophisticated rhythms and patterns above all else. BTBAM definitely delivers on those fronts, but they're so much more than that.

Sure, I can call them "progressive metal," but they're so much more than a genre. These are a different class of musicians that can truly play anything. Well okay, Blake might not be the absolute fastest drummer in the land. If speed is the metric by which you judge music, then you're limiting yourself a whole lot. There's more to life than machine gun double bass. Besides, Blake is still pretty damn fast.

So why metal, you ask? Well, for one thing, they're obviously friends. Heavy music is something they all bond over. It's fun for them. Everyone except Tommy (the singer) could easily be a session musician within any genre and may even make more money doing it, but that would probably be boring. Staying in BTBAM means they get to create things as friends. They get to challenge each other and build relationships as human beings. Tommy could (and does) write his own solo music that's not metal, but again, I'm sure he enjoys the experience of being in such an innovative band with his close friends.

**Side note:** What Tommy lacks in technical mastery of a single instrument, he makes up for in his storytelling.

---

I knew about BTBAM when they released their record *Alaska.* I didn't really get into it at the time. It's just not something my close friends listened to a lot. Someone showed me "Selkies" and I didn't really understand what happened after the intro. I didn't have as trained of an ear back then.

What really drew me to BTBAM was the album *Colors.* It's basically one long song divided into 8 tracks that clocks in at a little over an hour. It's a masterpiece. I've seen talk online about how it's overrated, but it really isn't. I'm so grateful for the way that singular album has shaped my musical perspective.

*Colors* is definitely a metal album, but it brings in several other genres like blues, jazz, post-rock, southern rock, and progressive rock. There are even multiple flavors of metal, like hardcore and death metal.

*Colors* isn't perfect. The drum fills at the end of "White Walls" during the guitar solos are a bit contrived, for instance. That actually might be my only problem with it. But oh man, "White Walls" was the first song I heard from the album and it absolutely blew me away.

<iframe src="https://embed.spotify.com/?uri=spotify%3Atrack%3A2P3dIKo1969QtGB7U1cKie" width="300" height="380" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

Anyway, after I had listened to *Colors* countless times and started to get slightly bored of it, I dove in to the rest of BTBAM's catalogue. Turns out, they had been doing innovative stuff with metal all along. *Colors* had definitely been produced at the highest quality and had the best song structure(s), but even on their very first self-titled album they had been very experimental and mixed other genres with metal.

I'll admit that I really only listen to two tracks off of *Between the Buried and Me,* and that's because they are the two that BTBAM included in their second set on *Colors Live.* The live versions of those songs are so much better.

<iframe src="https://embed.spotify.com/?uri=spotify%3Atrack%3A7KWE37VLtwlY6OWcDSIZST" width="300" height="380" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

*The Silent Circus* is a bit better in terms of production. It was at this point that BTBAM signed to Victory Records. A lot of those songs are actually pretty sinister. By that, I mean the music sounds evil and the lyrics are pretty badass too. I haven't listened to that album all the way through in a while; I should soon.

<iframe src="https://embed.spotify.com/?uri=spotify%3Atrack%3A20ww15KemlpsXO1KdiOigX" width="300" height="380" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

*Alaska* is better still, and that's the first album that drummer Blake Richardson, guitarist Dustie Waring, and bassist Dan Briggs appear on. So it appears that the two members really driving the experimentation from the beginning were vocalist Tommy Rogers and guitarist Paul Waggoner. But it wasn't until these three new members joined that the band became really tight and polished. *Alaska* reflects that. It also wasn't until *Alaska* that Tommy really matured vocally. It's super heavy, super experimental, and the production is great.

<iframe src="https://embed.spotify.com/?uri=spotify%3Atrack%3A2svPk1SpGvpRo8dM8nf6M8" width="300" height="380" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

Since we're talking about band members, it makes sense to mention the producer. Jamie King from The Basement Studios, located in Winston-Salem, North Carolina has produced almost all of BTBAM's albums. I think it's awesome that BTBAM was able to work with someone so close to home for most of their career, and that Jamie developed his talent alongside the band. The production unmistakably improves with each record (aside from *one* slight regression – more on that in the next two paragraphs).

---

After *Colors* and *Colors Live* comes *The Great Misdirect.* On the first listen through, I remember posting a Facebook status to the effect of, "That was the best listening experience I've ever had." I purposefully limited my exposure to the hype of the album and so I was hearing 99% of it for the first time. "Swim to the Moon," the last song on the 6-track album, was their best endeavor at song structure yet. I like to think of it as a modern-day *Rhapsody in Blue*. They did really cool things with "Fossil Genera" and "Disease, Injury, Madness" as well. And "Mirrors" is just plain beautiful.

<iframe src="https://embed.spotify.com/?uri=spotify%3Atrack%3A4yBg2OBVn8EaVAGL7CVy7c" width="300" height="380" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

The more I listened to the album, however, the more disappointed I became. The production, I felt, was a step backward from *Colors.* Some of the recording felt rushed and imperfect. The songs had clear beginnings and ends, like all of their previous albums except *Colors.*

Two years later, BTBAM got signed to Metal Blade, and then came *The Parallax: Hypersleep Dialogues* – a 3-track EP that was released with the promise of a full-length counterpart in the near future. The first song, "Specular Reflection," was another masterpiece! Probably their best one yet. That song exhibits a unique, expert use of motifs and reprises.

**Motif:** a short succession of notes producing a single impression; a brief melodic or rhythmic formula out of which longer passages are developed.

**Reprise:** a repeated passage in music.

<iframe src="https://embed.spotify.com/?uri=spotify%3Atrack%3A3t9glE2O1jHBUZqDqhJpZ5" width="300" height="380" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

Tommy begins telling a story with this EP, presumably to be carried over into the full-length sequel. However, I did not get into the story because I was only *obsessed* with 1/3 of the EP.

---

It wasn't until *The Parallax II: Future Sequence* that I really dove into Tommy's storytelling. I've got two words for you: space metal.

This album is the best of BTBAM. The songs once again have clear beginnings and ends, but there are several amazing motifs and reprises peppered throughout the album. (Besides, even on *Colors* you can hear the disconnect between songs, and not many people want to listen to an hour-long song anyway!) The heavy parts are **heavy** and the melodic parts are **melodic**, you know what I mean?

Tommy had included liner notes for his lyrics in the past, usually bundled with a special release of an album that included a live performance. *Colors Live* was one of them. So I did read those notes, and I've become obsessed with BTBAM lyrics in the past. I should refresh my memory because I've forgotten most of it. What I do remember is that Tommy's lyrics are often philosophical as opposed to a lot of metal lyrics, which are dick-swinging contests to see who can be the most grotesque. I remember being in high school, forming my own perspective on life, reading Tommy's lyrics, and being forced to think.

But it wasn't until I found [this series of posts](http://www.heavyblogisheavy.com/2012/07/24/prognotes-between-the-buried-and-mes-the-parallax-part-i-introduction/) that I really knew how deep Tommy's lyrics ran. Turns out, the Parallax story had actually begun on the first track of *The Silent Circus*. So you have parts of their entire catalogue setting the stage for *Parallax II*. And what an epic conclusion *Parallax II* is. Here's a taste.

> Regarding the concept of *The Parallax II: Future Sequence*, the new full-length album picks up where the 2011 EP, *The Parallax: Hypersleep Dialogues*, left off. The two main characters of the story take on a journey through space and time with the unenviable task of having to cure the flaws of humanity by any means necessary. While the EP served mostly as an introduction to the characters, *Future Sequence* contains the action of the story. The lyrics are written in the stream of consciousness style, which really helps to capture the perspective and emotion of the characters. We really enjoyed the challenge of writing this record, and I think we were all pleasantly surprised with how well the music and lyrics jived with one another. I couldn’t be happier with how *Future Sequence* turned out.

> – Paul Waggoner

<iframe src="https://embed.spotify.com/?uri=spotify%3Atrack%3A6f8nxx8zPqrctU6kLphyHS" width="300" height="380" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

---

So now we reach *Coma Ecliptic.* The overall style of the album is similar to *Parallax II:* songs with clear beginnings and ends, motifs and reprises that transcend songs, and one unifying story (which I still need to dive into). The album marks a clear evolution and maturity of the band's sound. The production is far and away the best of any BTBAM album. So... why is it so boring?

It's boring because of two main reasons. 1.) It's not as heavy, and 2.) it's more repetitive. Those two together mean that "it's just not as metal, man." I've seen talk online about how "BTBAM is basically prog rock now," and I'm sure some people would even go as far as saying they've sold out. I don't think so. I think they will definitely be able to reach a wider audience with *Coma Ecliptic,* which makes me happy for them. But for me, *Coma Ecliptic* just doesn't feel **familiar.**

Not all of it is unfamiliar. Two songs remind me of BTBAM: "The Ectopic Stroll" and "Memory Palace." And when I go see them live, I'll be hoping that they play those two songs and the rest will be old goodies. I'm so glad "The Ectopic Stroll" made the album. It represents the best of BTBAM, and truly is *Coma Ecliptic's* saving grace.

<iframe src="https://embed.spotify.com/?uri=spotify%3Atrack%3A7HttAGuRTcBF7Yz40kzlWh" width="300" height="380" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

---

If anything, *Coma Ecliptic* has made me appreciate *The Great Misdirect* for what it really is – a damn good album. I can't stop listening to "Disease, Injury, Madness," and I now hold that song in the same regard I hold "Specular Reflection."

<iframe src="https://embed.spotify.com/?uri=spotify%3Atrack%3A0mrjr2OJ8MjWZnSXi3s4i9" width="300" height="380" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true"></iframe>

---

When BTBAM's next album comes out, I'll definitely give it a shot. But, I'm predicting that I will be disappointed. That doesn't mean I think BTBAM should go back to their old ways – I understand the change and how it benefits them, and I honestly couldn't be happier. Keep doin' you, fam.

In the meantime, for the first time in my life, I'll be that crotchety guy reminiscing about the good ol' days.

Tommy begins telling a story with this EP, presumably to be carried over into the full-length sequel. However, I did not get into the story because I was only obsessed with 1/3 of the EP.

It wasn't until The Parallax II: Future Sequence that I really dove into Tommy's storytelling. I've got two words for you: space metal.

This album is the best of BTBAM. The songs once again have clear beginnings and ends, but there are several amazing motifs and reprises peppered throughout the album. (Besides, even on Colors you can hear the disconnect between songs, and not many people want to listen to an hour-long song anyway!) The heavy parts are heavy and the melodic parts are melodic, you know what I mean?

Tommy had included liner notes for his lyrics in the past, usually bundled with a special release of an album that included a live performance. Colors Live was one of them. So I did read those notes, and I've become obsessed with BTBAM lyrics in the past. I should refresh my memory because I've forgotten most of it. What I do remember is that Tommy's lyrics are often philosophical as opposed to a lot of metal lyrics, which are dick-swinging contests to see who can be the most grotesque. I remember being in high school, forming my own perspective on life, reading Tommy's lyrics, and being forced to think.

But it wasn't until I found this series of posts that I really knew how deep Tommy's lyrics ran. Turns out, the Parallax story had actually begun on the first track of The Silent Circus. So you have parts of their entire catalogue setting the stage for Parallax II. And what an epic conclusion Parallax II is. Here's a taste.

Regarding the concept of The Parallax II: Future Sequence, the new full-length album picks up where the 2011 EP, The Parallax: Hypersleep Dialogues, left off. The two main characters of the story take on a journey through space and time with the unenviable task of having to cure the flaws of humanity by any means necessary. While the EP served mostly as an introduction to the characters, Future Sequence contains the action of the story. The lyrics are written in the stream of consciousness style, which really helps to capture the perspective and emotion of the characters. We really enjoyed the challenge of writing this record, and I think we were all pleasantly surprised with how well the music and lyrics jived with one another. I couldn’t be happier with how Future Sequence turned out.

– Paul Waggoner

So now we reach Coma Ecliptic. The overall style of the album is similar to Parallax II: songs with clear beginnings and ends, motifs and reprises that transcend songs, and one unifying story (which I still need to dive into). The album marks a clear evolution and maturity of the band's sound. The production is far and away the best of any BTBAM album. So... why is it so boring?

It's boring because of two main reasons. 1.) It's not as heavy, and 2.) it's more repetitive. Those two together mean that "it's just not as metal, man." I've seen talk online about how "BTBAM is basically prog rock now," and I'm sure some people would even go as far as saying they've sold out. I don't think so. I think they will definitely be able to reach a wider audience with Coma Ecliptic, which makes me happy for them. But for me, Coma Ecliptic just doesn't feel familiar.

Not all of it is unfamiliar. Two songs remind me of BTBAM: "The Ectopic Stroll" and "Memory Palace." And when I go see them live, I'll be hoping that they play those two songs and the rest will be old goodies. I'm so glad "The Ectopic Stroll" made the album. It represents the best of BTBAM, and truly is Coma Ecliptic's saving grace.

If anything, Coma Ecliptic has made me appreciate The Great Misdirect for what it really is – a damn good album. I can't stop listening to "Disease, Injury, Madness," and I now hold that song in the same regard I hold "Specular Reflection."

When BTBAM's next album comes out, I'll definitely give it a shot. But, I'm predicting that I will be disappointed. That doesn't mean I think BTBAM should go back to their old ways – I understand the change and how it benefits them, and I honestly couldn't be happier. Keep doin' you, fam.

In the meantime, for the first time in my life, I'll be that crotchety guy reminiscing about the good ol' days.

posts.title: A Tiny Reading List
posts.markdown:
![Cool Bookcase](/content/images/2016/07/books-1.jpeg)

I haven't read anything in a long time, but now that I have to commute an hour and a half to my new job, I have lots of time for audiobooks. I have created a wish list in Audible reflecting the recommendations and/or gifts I've received from friends, family, and coworkers.

I have discovered that Audible's subscription really only covers one book per month, which might be suitable for someone with say a 30 minute commute. I may have to check out some audiobooks from the good ol' public library in between Audible credits. Someone told me you could put those on your phone. Anyway, here's my wish list, which I will update as I progress:

- ~~*Brave New World* by Aldous Huxley~~
- ~~*Cat's Cradle* by Kurt Vonnegut~~
- ~~*House of Leaves* by Mark Z. Danielewski~~
- ~~*Coyote Blue* by Christopher Moore~~
- *The Gunslinger* by Stephen King
- *Harry Potter* series by J.K. Rowling (re-read)
- *Science Set Free* by Rupert Sheldrake
- *Hamilton: The Revolution* by Lin-Manuel Miranda and Jeremy McCarter
- *Yes Please* by Amy Poehler

Feel free to include recommendations in the comments below!
